comment.author: 29664332@N00
comment._content:
highly probable that it is a student in charge of them...a town like this would have had a 1 or 2 room school where the older children would be tasked with helping the younger ones learn....most of these kids wouldn't have finished the 7th or 8th grade anyway given that they'd start having to work around the age of 14-15 on the homesteads...
as per the shoes....well, this is just coming out of the depression..many folks from that time talk about only getting one pair of shoes a year at christmas and these would be used for shcool and church only..not going to the fair...though they do seem to be in their sunday best even though alot of the material comes from the large flour sacks of the time period....even a pllowcase was used to make one girls outfit.....there are a few store bought items there too..
the ads are because they are at a fair..not at school..

comment.author: 10118832@N04
comment._content: According to photo captions elsewhere in this wonderful collection (http://flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2179135002/; flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2178351723/), school was held in the Farm Bureau building, where this interior shot may have been taken. In a town this size, public multi-use buildings would have been a necessity, and the advertising signs on the proscenium make more sense there.

comment.author: 29523042@N03
comment._content: The Whinery Children- The boys: Oldest boy is A.J. Whinery, baby boy is Lawrence Whinery. The girls: Oldest girl is Laura Whinery, Wanda Whinery is in white, and Velva Whinery is in pink. Velva's middle name is Mae, and her obituary is here. It says she was born in Adrin, TX, Lawrence and Wanda passed away before Velva, and as far as I know Laura and A.J are still alive. At the time of Velva's passing, Laura lived in Clifton, CO with the married name Murray, and Jack lived in Clifton. It doesn't say which of the many Cliftons it is, so I am guessing it is Clifton, TX. A married name was not listed for Wanda, so I assume she never married. While I found the obit. on the internet, I found the names of the other children while in Pie Town the other day. It was a photographer's dream!
